translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The third section🔽The discussion of the divine eye

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the fleshly eye, when it is supported by the Dhamma, the divine eye?
“Yes.”

analyzed: masa cakkhum dibba cakkhu dibba cakkhum masa cakkhunti
translated: Is the fleshly eye the divine eye, and is the divine eye the fleshly eye?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye sense-sphere and in the mind-object sense-sphere?” …

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the fleshly eye, when it is supported by the Dhamma, the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: Yādisaṁ maṁsacakkhuṁ tādisaṁ dibbacakkhuṁ, yādisaṁ dibbacakkhuṁ tādisaṁ maṁsacakkhunti?
analyzed: yādisam masa cakkhum tādisam dibba cakkhu yādisam dibba cakkhum tādisam masa cakkhunti
translated: Is the divine eye the same as the fleshly eye, and is the fleshly eye the same as the divine eye?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the fleshly eye, when it is supported by the Dhamma, the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: Taññeva maṁsacakkhuṁ taṁ dibbacakkhuṁ, taṁ dibbacakkhuṁ taṁ maṁsacakkhunti?
analyzed: tam dibba cakkhu tam dibba cakkhum tam masa cakkhunti
translated: Is the fleshly eye the same as the divine eye, and is the divine eye the same as the fleshly eye?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the fleshly eye, when it is supported by the Dhamma, the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: Yādiso maṁsacakkhussa visayo ānubhāvo gocaro tādiso dibbassa cakkhussa visayo ānubhāvo gocaroti?
analyzed: yādisaḥ masa cakkhussa visayaḥ ānubhāvaḥ gocaro tādisaḥ dibbassa cakkhussa visayaḥ ānubhāvaḥ gocaro ti
translated: Is the range, the mastery, the domain of the divine eye the same as the range, the mastery, the domain of the fleshly eye?
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: “Is the eye faculty, when it is dependent on the Dhamma, the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: upādinnam hutvā an upādinnam hoti iti
translated: “Having been appropriated, does it become unappropriated?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: upādinnam hutvā an upādinnam hoti iti
translated: “Having been appropriated, does it become unappropriated?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: kāma avacaram hutvā rūpa avacaram hoti iti
translated: “Having been of the sense-sphere, does it become of the fine-material sphere?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: kāma avacaram hutvā rūpa avacaram hoti iti
translated: “Having been of the sense-sphere, does it become of the fine-material sphere?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: rūpāvacaram hutvā a rūpāvacaram hoti iti
translated: “Having been of the fine-material sphere, does it become of the immaterial sphere?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: rūpāvacaram hutvā a rūpāvacaram hoti iti
translated: “Having been of the fine-material sphere, does it become of the immaterial sphere?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: pariyāpannam hutvā a pariyāpannam hoti iti
translated: “Having been included, does it become not included?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: “Is the eye faculty, when it is dependent on the Dhamma, the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: dibba cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham masa cakkhum hoti iti
translated: “Is the divine eye, when it is dependent on the Dhamma, the eye faculty?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: “Is the eye faculty, when it is dependent on the Dhamma, the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: dibba cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham paññā cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the divine eye the eye of the Dhamma that is focused on the mind?
You shouldn’t say that.

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the eye of the Dhamma the divine eye that is focused on the mind?
Yes.

analyzed: dibba cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham masa cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the divine eye the eye of the Dhamma that is focused on the mind?
You shouldn’t say that.

analyzed: masa cakkhum dhamma upatthaddham dibba cakkhum hoti iti
translated: Is the eye of the Dhamma the divine eye that is focused on the mind?
Yes.
Are there two eyes?
You shouldn’t say that.
Are there two eyes?
Yes.
But haven’t three eyes been stated by the Buddha:

analyzed: masa cakkhu dibba cakkhu paññā cakkhunti
translated: the eye of the flesh, the divine eye, and the eye of wisdom?

analyzed: āmantā  hañci tīṇi cakkhūni vuttāni bhagavatā
translated: Yes.

original: maṁsacakkhuṁ, dibbacakkhuṁ, paññācakkhuṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: masa cakkhu dibba cakkhu paññā cakkhu no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: Well then, you shouldn’t say that
“there are two eyes.”
Are there two eyes?
Yes.
But hasn’t it been said by the Buddha:
“Monks, there are these three eyes.
What three?

analyzed: masa cakkhu dibba cakkhu paññā cakkhunti
translated: The eye of the flesh, the divine eye, and the eye of wisdom.

analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave tīṇi cakkhūni iti
translated: These are the three kinds of eyes.”
“The eye of flesh, the divine eye,
And the unsurpassed wisdom-eye:
These are the three eyes
Proclaimed by the best of men.
The arising of the eye of flesh
Is the path to the divine eye.

analyzed: yadā ca ñāṇam udapādi  paññācakkhum anuttara
translated: When knowledge arose in me,🔽The unsurpassed wisdom-eye:
The acquisition of that eye
Liberates one from all suffering.”
Is there a sutta on this?
“Yes.”
“Well then, you shouldn’t say that there are only two kinds of eyes.”
The account of the divine eye is finished.
